meanings.def: the highest part or point of something
examples: at the top of something She was standing at the top of the stairs.
The title is right at the top of the page.
at the top Write your name at the top.
to the top He filled my glass to the top.
to the top of something We climbed to the very top of the hill.
on the top Snow was falling on the mountain tops.
on the top of something He was completely bald on the top of his head.
I was out of breath when I reached the top.
(British English) the top of the milk (= the cream that rises to the top of a bottle of milk)
The wind was blowing in the tops of the trees.

meanings.def: the upper flat surface of something
examples: Can you polish the top of the table?

meanings.def: a piece of clothing worn on the upper part of the body
examples: I need a top to go with this skirt.
a tracksuit/bikini/pyjama top
He was wearing a blue hooded top.
She wore a pink skirt with a matching top.

meanings.def: a thing that you put on the end of something to close it
examples: Where's the top of this pen?
a bottle with a screw top
a jar with a tight-fitting lid
a bath plug
He popped the top of a soda can.
We used to collect milk bottle tops for charity.

meanings.def: the highest or most important rank or position
examples: at the top of something They finished the season at the top of the league.
He's at the top of his profession.
We have a lot of things to do, but packing is at the top of the list.
at the top The company needs to make a change at the top.
to the top She is determined to make it to the top (= achieve fame or success).
He worked his way to the top in just a few short years.
to the top of something The album shot straight to the top of the charts.
The issue has recently risen to the top of the agenda.
I would not have gone into boxing if I didn't think I could reach the top.
This decision came from the top.
The company has an unusually high proportion of young people at the top.
Pay was now at the top of the employees' agenda.

meanings.def: the end of a street, table, etc. that is furthest away from you or from where you usually come to it
examples: I'll meet you at the top of Thorpe Street.

meanings.def: the leaves of a plant that is grown mainly for its root
examples: Remove the green tops from the carrots.

meanings.def: used after an amount of money, time, etc. to show that it is the highest, longest, etc. possible
examples: It couldn't have cost more than £50, tops.
It'll take a couple of hours, tops.

meanings.def: a person or thing of the best quality
examples: Among sports superstars she’s (the) tops.
In the survey the Brits come out tops for humour.

meanings.def: a child’s toy that turns round on a point when it is moved very quickly by hand or by a string
examples: She was so confused—her mind was spinning like a top.

meanings.def: high up/low down in the structure of an organization or a society
examples: These workers are at the bottom of the economic heap.

meanings.def: in the highest position or rank in a profession or career
as loudly as possible
examples: She was screaming at the top of her voice.
I was shouting at the top of my voice but she couldn't hear me.

meanings.def: to get very angry
in the least/most important position in a group of people or things
examples: It’s been 20 years since a British player was top of the pile.
The government is doing little to help those at the bottom of the social pile.

meanings.def: to win a contest or an argument
examples: In most boardroom disputes he tends to come out on top.

meanings.def: going to every part of a place in a very careful way
examples: We cleaned the house from top to bottom.

meanings.def: completely; all over
examples: She was dressed in green from top to toe.

meanings.def: to be too much for somebody to manage or deal with
examples: All this extra work is getting on top of him.

meanings.def: to manage to control or deal with something
examples: How will I ever get on top of all this work?

meanings.def: just guessing or using your memory, without taking time to think carefully or check the facts
examples: I can't remember the name off the top of my head, but I can look it up for you.

meanings.def: on the highest point or surface
examples: a cake with cream on top
Stand on top and look down.

meanings.def: in a leading position or in control
examples: She remained on top for the rest of the match.

meanings.def: in addition
examples: Look, here's 30 dollars, and I'll buy you lunch on top.

meanings.def: on, over or covering something/somebody
examples: Books were piled on top of one another.
There was a vase on top of the bookcase.
Many people were crushed when the building collapsed on top of them.

meanings.def: in addition to something
examples: He gets commission on top of his salary.
On top of everything else, my car's been stolen.

meanings.def: very close to something/somebody
examples: We were all living on top of each other in that tiny apartment.

meanings.def: in control of a situation
examples: Do you think he's really on top of his job?
Work tends to pile up if I don’t keep on top of it.

meanings.def: very happy or proud
done with too much acting, emotion or effort
examples: His performance is completely over the top.
an over-the-top reaction

meanings.def: to go back to the beginning of a song, piece of music, etc. and repeat it
examples: OK, everybody, let's take it from the top.

meanings.def: with little or no hair on the head
examples: He's starting to get a little thin on top (= he's losing his hair).
He's going bald on top.

meanings.def: used to talk about a person’s intelligence
examples: He hasn't got much up top (= he isn't very intelligent).
It’s what’s up top (= how intelligent you are) that matters.

meanings.def: highest in position
examples: He lives on the top floor.
She kept her passport in the top drawer.
The score is in the top left-hand corner of the screen.

meanings.def: highest in rank, degree or importance
examples: He's one of the top players in the country.
She got the top job.
top officials/executives/aides
He finished top in the exam.
She was top in English.
He was top of the class in geography.
She got top marks for her essay.
They're top of the league.
The club can claim top spot in the league with a victory.
The athletes are all on top form (= performing their best).
He was City's top scorer last season.
Welfare reform is a top priority for the government.
The car was travelling at top speed.
Who won the top prize?
Prices at the top end of the market are coming down.
top quality silk

meanings.def: very good
examples: He's a top bloke.

meanings.def: to be higher than a particular amount
examples: Worldwide sales look set to top $1 billion.

meanings.def: to be in the highest position on a list because you are the most successful, important, etc.
examples: The band topped the charts for five weeks with their first single.

meanings.def: to put something on the top of something else
examples: be topped by/with something The chapel was topped by a dome of white marble.
fruit salad topped with cream

meanings.def: to say or do something that is better, funnier, more impressive, etc. than something that somebody else has said or done in the past
examples: I'm afraid the other company has topped your offer (= offered more money).
He has a house in five European capitals—how do you top that?
It was a wonderful performance, and I challenge anyone to top that.
Topping all the others by far, the award went to one of Hollywood's most respected actors.

meanings.def: to kill yourself deliberately
to reach the highest point of a hill, etc.
to cut the top and bottom parts off fruit and vegetables to prepare them to be cooked or eaten
used to introduce the final piece of information that is worse than the other bad things that you have just mentioned
examples: And then, to top it all, it started to rain!
